marklogic.body:
When you are sworn into military service, you take an oath to defend the Constitution and also to be subordinate to lawful superior officers. You also become subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice which curtails some due process and other rights afforded the general citizenry. That's part of the gig. Taking an openly adversarial position against your commander (in this case, commander-in-chief) has Always been grounds for disciplinary action. This guy should have known better, or be willing to take the Heat.
I held plenty of political disagreements with the POTUS during my 7 years active duty, but had no problem with order, discipline, and proper subordination. This is clearly a breach of all three of those things.
